key_points: Former President Donald Trump's second impeachment moves to the Senate on Feb. 9 for trial, following charges of 'incitement of insurrection'.
The impeachment was a response to the Jan. 6 Capitol riot by pro-Trump supporters during the Electoral College vote count.
House Democrats, led by Rep. Jamie Raskin, serve as the prosecution team against Trump.
Trump's defense team, smaller than in his first impeachment trial, is led by David Schoen and Bruce Castor Jr.
The impeachment marked the most bipartisan vote in history, with 10 House Republicans supporting.
Senate trial procedures include presentation of evidence, trial duration, and witness testimonies.
Sen. Patrick Leahy presides over the trial, with the Senate acting as the jury.
A conviction could prevent Trump from holding federal office, subject to a subsequent Senate vote.
35 Republican senators have indicated they will vote against conviction, enough to acquit Trump according to statements collected by USA TODAY.
Only three presidents including Trump have faced Senate impeachment trials; Trump is the only one impeached twice.
